notes: Higher extrapolation order reduces bias but increases variance exponentially.
Unbiased but extreme sampling overhead that grows exponentially with circuit depth.
Per-layer noise scaling reduces bias vs global ZNE at cost of more circuit variants.
Bias depends on how well near-Clifford training circuits match target noise; low variance at inference.
Bias from model expressivity limits; variance controlled by training data quantity.
Nearly unbiased if calibration is accurate; variance from inverting the confusion matrix.
No sampling overhead; residual bias from finite pulse width and higher-order terms.
Does not reduce noise magnitude, only converts coherent errors to stochastic.
Post-selection discards data, increasing effective variance; bias depends on noise type.
Bias suppressed exponentially in number of copies M; overhead is M copies of the circuit.
Quality depends on subspace basis; additional measurements needed for matrix elements.
Purely classical post-processing; bias reduction depends on constraint tightness.
No bias in certification bound; overhead from running trap circuits.
Residual bias from undetectable errors O(p^d); post-selection reduces effective sample size.
